posts.name: Amit sucher
posts.cooked: Throughout the years I am pretty sure we always used polycarb for our belly pan, but I keep seeing many teams use aluminium instead of polycarb. So I was wondering what is the advantage aluminium has over polycarb as the belly pan material

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked: Our team uses it because we have a lot of it and it can sometimes be lighter I believe, just make sure to get it somewhat thin 1/8in or 1/16in (we use something like that I think) that thickness allows us to mount some features directly to our belly pan(climb winch was mounted there but somewhat of an afterthought). hope this helps:)

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked:
Two main benefits:

Increased stiffness. Especially with the current meta of corner-biased swerve modules which result in long unsupported frame rails only connected by three or four bolts at the extreme end of the tubes, drivetrains can lack significantly in stiffness necessary for a robust base and repeatable mechanisms. Aluminum will do a better job at stiffening your robot, although any sort of bellypan/brainpan or extra cross members will help to some extent.

Extra weight down low. As long as you have the weight to spare, the brainpan/bellypan along with the frame rails is pretty much the lowest part of your robot that you can easily add mass to to lower your center of gravity, to the point where teams have often switched to steel pans and/or tubes (even solid steel tubes) when they have weight to spare to get their base as stable as possible to prevent tipping and improve acceleration behavior.

posts.name: Sean Paxman I 9191
posts.cooked: Typically you want as low a centre of gravity as possible, having an ali or even steel bellypan helps a lot with this. Sometimes you might also want to mount things like gearboxes to the bellypan, rigid ali is a lot better than polycarb in this regard. We use a 25mm ali billet drivebase to improve drivebase rigidity, lower cg, and allow for custom mounting and wire routing solutions.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
This MAY be the last year polycarb bellypans are going to be “relevant”.  With SystemCore coming in the next year (26-27…with possible use at Worlds this season)…aluminum will be the primary bellypan due to it being a heat sink.

Now, doing a “hybrid” of the 2 is possible (a split bellypan)…or mounting to the superstructure like the Radio.

We have only run aluminum bellypans…I thought about suggesting a polycarb bellypan to the team for just this year…I may have to change my mind…or do it anyway!
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

…with possible use at Worlds this season

Without derailing too much, I find it peculiar that FIRST would consider changing such a critical/core component (far more so than when they did this with the radio’s in 2024) for teams at Worlds.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
Using past “innovations”.  The new radio is a prime example.

Plus, I used the word “possible” for a reason.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.cooked:
We tried a belly pan for the first time this past season. We used 1/8" aluminum and cut out squares in the corners for the swerve modules.

What I took away as the most useful aspects of the belly pan:

Low center of gravity: We play a lot of defense and a low center of gravity is a must. Almost half our weight was in our drivetrain and it made us almost immovable.

Protection: While it is rare, the belly pan stopped game pieces and other robots from damaging our robot from beneath

Easy mounting: Almost every part of our robot was mounted to the belly pan. This made it very easy (just a couple bolts) to fully remove a mechanism from our robot to replace or repair it.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
[FRC Blog] FIRST® Championship Information (REAL) General Forum

This is what I was referring to.  I do agree that this is a HUGE if.  Too much rewiring unlike the radio.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: We used a polycarb bellypan last year, and we used an Aluminum one this year, and the biggest benefit was probably the durability and stiffness. We didn’t have to worry about it breaking at all, and it never had bending issues, and, as mentioned before, it has superior heat sinking capabilites. We didn’t have the spare weight to make it super heavy, so we pocketed it, but one of the consequences of this was that it took a long time to machine and we couldn’t drill more holes in it, so once it was made pretty early in the season, we couldn’t really make any changes to it, which was never a huge issue, but being able to quickly move things around when it was helpful would’ve been nice during the later weeks of build season and comp season, but in the end we managed without having to change it at all during the season.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: There is zero chance that there is a switch to SystemCore at champs next year. The radio was switched due to known issues with the old radios, especially in high-traffic environments like the 8 simultaneous fields at champs. The RoboRIO does not have the same kind of known serious issues that would warrant a switch of that magnitude. Not to mention that beta testing is still planned for next off-season ahead of delivery to all teams in 2027, so they would be running a device that is not fully tested.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
We’ve run both types.  Having a bellypan at all is a major step up in chassis stiffness!  The largest value is connecting the corners, but tying in the perimeter beams is also big plus, as it adds side impact resistance/stiffness.  As for aluminum vs polycarb vs steel, my feeling is that its more a question of which material works better in your build process.  It may be the largest part on the robot, and the #2 heaviest if its a steel plate.  You use steel if you want ballast; pretty much end of story…

As for stiffness, the elastic modulus runs steel, aluminum, plastic.  Density runs the same way.  More often than not, polycarb bellypans are thicker than aluminum ones.  1/16" aluminum is pretty solid.  1/16" polycarb is getting kinda floppy.  IE, when you push down on it, it moves excessively.  The X brace aspect is mostly driven by “is there -anything- connecting the corners” and uses tension in the material.  Side impact needs a bit more wrinkle resistance to be valuable, so there’s some motivation for some thickness.  I’d suggest leaving some solid areas near the perimeter beams if you are running lightening holes.  I’d go for at least 2" wide, maybe 3".  If you want to get fancy, go somewhat triangular.

posts.name: Emerson OHara
posts.cooked:
Zaque:

Increased stiffness.

This! I’m surprised people don’t talk about this more. Even a 1/16" aluminum shear panel connected on all 4 edges adds an incredible about of stiffness to the frame of a robot.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: If you have a steel belly pan you don’t have to worry much about your frame bending and it helps keep your CoG low but you do need to have a smaller frame and otherwise lighter bot.

It will still require an aluminum mount or bellypan/brainpan for mounting. This is a given from what I have read. Much like the radio…it will need a heatsink. PC will not work for it…might as well get use to using aluminum…if you aren’t already.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked:
For many/most teams the best option is still a 1/2"+ thick sheet of plywood or MDF.  At that thickness you get good stiffness and durability while being much easier to manufacture than aluminum and 10% of the cost of aluminum or polycarb.  It is so inexpensive that you can make a big design change and simply throw out the old pan without any pain.

Some added benefits are no electrical conductivity, no metal shavings if you drill a hole, and the possibility of directly screwing down small things like cable clips with wood screws instead of through bolts.  We used 3/4" MDF last year and used a cheapo CNC router to make pockets for equipment mounts and cable channels.

We’ve started using .25" a36 steel for our bellypans since 2024. The added stiffness and lowered COG can’t be understated, especially for a year that saw so many bent chassis rails. They normally weigh around 30lbs ish?

Sorry to the Fabworks and FedEx guys who have to ship these things.

posts.name: topgun
posts.cooked: For the steel and aluminum teams, don’t you worry about electrical conductivity, or are you doing something to isolate the electrical components from the belly pan?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: No special isolation efforts.  Remember that the robot power MUST be isolated from the frame.  Nothing in the system has built-in frame grounding.
